$ZIM Here's another downside to short-selling you might not have thought of yet.
Q: I shorted a large amount of a dividend-paying stock and was surprised that its latest quarterly dividend was deducted from my brokerage account. Why did I have to pay it?
There are several downsides to short-selling. You have unlimited loss potential
created_at: the market has an inherent positive bias over the long run
column3: you'll probably have to pay a fee for borrowing the shares
column5: you are responsible for paying any dividends issued by the stock while you're short.

body: Here's why. Consider the basic mechanism of how short-selling works.

created_at: you're borrowing shares from someone else (typically your brokerage firm) and selling them on the open market. Your hope is that the stock's price goes down
column3: so you can repurchase and return the borrowed shares for less than you sold them for.
